I think the most logical way to bring Vibrant Visuals to lower-end devices is to essentially create a “lite” version. Bringing every detail of Vibrant Visuals will simply not be possible for particularly low-end devices. To toss some numbers out, it takes ~1.3 TFLOPS to ~0.8 TFLOPS to run it, ~0.8 being the absolute minimum. To bring it, for example, to my PC which is only capable of ~0.4 TFLOPS, they would have to take the already minimum requirement and cut it in half. They stated in the release article “with the hope of bringing this graphics revamp (either fully or partially) to as many devices as possible” suggesting a “lite” “version” of sorts may already be in the works. They are also still testing more devices.

It is hard to technically elaborate any further simply because they haven’t released all of the minimum requirements for Vibrant Visuals, only vague guidelines. (In my case with my PC, they stated it requires being able to run Minecraft on DX12, which it is perfectly capable of doing, yet still is grayed out, meaning there are more requirements that are not yet specified, hence the TFLOPS gap.) Vibrant Visuals as a feature is also still young, and as stated in their 1.21.80 Bedrock changelog, they are constantly re-iterating and developing Vibrant Visuals. :D

For consoles, mojang should add the option for the game to render at native 1080p when connected to a 1080p screen (or when the console resolution output is manually changed to 1080p even if the console is connected to a 4k screen). Currently, the ps5 version is always rendering at 4k, even when connected to a 1080p monitor, which is why performance is very unstable (because 4k is very demanding on the hardware). By changing the rendered resolution to 1080p, the performance should improve significantly, resulting in more people being able to enjoy Vibrant Visuals at a stable 60 fps on their devices.

I personally do not like the new visuals that were added to Minecraft. It doesn't give the classic nostalgic Minecraft vibe that it used to. The water doesn't look like water anymore. It is clear, and you can see straight through to the bottom; and once there, the bottom looks like a coral reef everywhere. There is a haze that covers the land, and while it may be cool in certain biomes, like the swamp or deep forest, being in a biome like the grassland just doesn't make sense. And it doesn't look good. On top of that, some of the woods don't look their classic color, with Spruce wood looking orange. Not even close to it's actual color in real life, which is more of the classic Minecraft Birch color. And, everything has a slight sparkle to it. It definitely looks like it updated... into the past. 

While this update was supposed to make the worlds look brighter, and possibly more realistic, I think that it did just the opposite. It looks like it went back to a 1970's game with pixelated graphics and hazy visuals. 

Please consider removing the vibrant visuals, or adding an option to remove the vibrant visuals per player.

When we heard about Vibrant Visuals coming to Minecraft: Bedrock Edition, we were ecstatic! Please highly consider adding for Vibrant Visuals so Fire Tablet users can eagerly play the new update! We just hate that everybody else gets to play the new update and use the new Vibrant Visuals feature but us Fire Tablet users can not! So basically lets just say this: most Amazon Fire devices aren't exactly designed for Minecraft gaming, especially not Minecraft's equivalent of shaders (vibrant visuals). So VV will probably not come close to the classic fire range of tablets. The fire pros will have a decent shot at it, but still.

Plus even some next gen consoles can't run VV at a full 120fps, so the classic Amazon Fires will probably never touch VV.

On the other hand, Switch 2 users will probably have an 85% chance of getting VV.

But please consider printing VV to most (or all) platforms, optimizing it and maximising VV sliders and toggles on the way!

Soy un jugador de Minecraft Bedrock que ha logrado correr la actualización _Vibrant Visuals_ en un dispositivo con procesador *Helio G88*, a pesar de que no está oficialmente soportado. Mediante ajustes personalizados, texturas optimizadas como Barebones, y modificaciones al código del juego, he conseguido alcanzar entre *60 y 70 FPS* con una experiencia visual bastante fluida.

Entiendo que Mojang busca garantizar una experiencia estable para todos los jugadores, pero muchos de nosotros estamos dispuestos a ajustar configuraciones manualmente con tal de disfrutar de los nuevos efectos visuales. Por eso, propongo lo siguiente:

*Incluir una opción en los ajustes del juego para activar Vibrant Visuals manualmente*, incluso en dispositivos no oficialmente compatibles, acompañada de una advertencia como:

> “Esta función no está optimizada para tu dispositivo. Activarla puede afectar el rendimiento.

Vibrant Visuals Missing on Switch 2 – A Disgrace
Vibrant Visuals delivers stunning Minecraft upgrades—volumetric fog, directional lighting, enhanced water—standard on Xbox, PS5, and high-end PCs. Yet months after launch, Nintendo Switch 2 gets nothing. The community is furious: nearly 300 upvotes and dozens of comments demand a dedicated Switch 2 edition with Vibrant Visuals, higher render distance, and Joy-Con mouse mode. The hardware can handle it—original Switch runs Cyberpunk 2077 and 10,000 TNT explosions. No technical barrier exists.
So why the silence? Microsoft holds the answer. As Mojang’s owner, they prioritize Xbox and PC to funnel players into their ecosystem. Nintendo is a direct rival. Why invest in enhancing a competitor’s platform? Better to leave Switch users with outdated visuals—or push them to buy an Xbox. Negotiations with Nintendo likely stall over licensing, costs, or cold corporate strategy.
In 2025, this exclusion is outrageous. Minecraft thrives on cross-play and accessibility. Instead, an entire device family is locked out of core upgrades—not because it can’t run them, but due to corporate rivalry. It’s anti-player, anti-community, and a betrayal of Minecraft’s spirit. Switch 2 deserves Vibrant Visuals now.

Les nuages sont devenus… un peu trop timides ! 

Je rejoins totalement cet avis. Depuis la mise à jour 1.21.80.25, les nuages semblent beaucoup plus fins qu’avant. Cela casse un peu l’ambiance visuelle iconique et immersive de Minecraft. Dans la version 1.21.70, les nuages avaient une belle densité, une vraie présence dans le ciel. Aujourd’hui, ils paraissent presque effacés…

Si l’idée est de rénover le rendu des nuages, pourquoi ne pas aller plus loin en innovant ?

  • Ajouter une épaisseur variable pour chaque nuage, pour un ciel plus vivant.

  • Leur faire occuper différentes altitudes, avec des effets de transparence réalistes selon leur hauteur.

Ce genre d’ajouts rendrait le ciel plus dynamique, plus naturel, sans trahir le style cubique de Minecraft que nous aimons tous.

Merci pour votre superbe travail sur Vibrant Visuals, mais n’oublions pas : un beau ciel, c’est ce qui donne de la magie aux mondes que nous créons.

Here is an English translation of the above French comment, which I totally agree with! 

The clouds have become… a little too shy! 

I totally agree with this opinion. Since the 1.21.80.25 update , the clouds seem much thinner than before. This breaks the iconic and immersive visual atmosphere of Minecraft a little. In version 1.21.70 , the clouds had a nice density, a real presence in the sky. Today, they seem almost erased...

If the idea is to renovate the rendering of clouds, why not go further by innovating?

  • Add varying thickness for each cloud, for a more vibrant sky.

  • Make them occupy different altitudes , with realistic transparency effects depending on their height.

These kinds of additions would make the sky more dynamic, more natural , without betraying the cubic style of Minecraft that we all love.

Thanks for your great work on Vibrant Visuals , but let's not forget: beautiful skies are what make the worlds we create magical.
they should also make cloud shadows more soft, because the current ones look strange. Additionally, thicker clouds would have more intense shadows.
Clouds can be dynamic, so they alternate between when it starts to rain and when it becomes a beautiful sunny day.
The outline around clouds should be reduced slightly.

I totally agree with this view!

Over the past period of time, Minecraft has not made any significant changes regarding the cloud aspect.

We should add more things of the clouds in Minecraft!

For instance, add cumulonimbus clouds, cumulus clouds, cumulus fractus clouds, alto clouds, cirrus clouds, cirrostratus clouds... and even some unique halos!

 

 

 

I have visited a nature reserve. The environment there is similar to that in Minecraft, But the clouds in there are ever-changing and come in various shaps, while in Minecraft, there are only a few thin clouds floating in the sky at any given time.

I think Minecraft should have more clouds: on sunny days, let there be cumulus clouds, cirrus clouds (it seems a bit complicated to create this model. You could add a halo to the sun when it's in the cirrus clouds) or altostratus clouds moving slowly across the sky, or no clouds at all; during the transition period between sunny and rainy days (or let Minecraft add the cloudy days), let high clouds, cumulonimbus clouds or stratocumulus clouds hang in the sky; during rainy days, let cumulonimbus clouds make the sky feel gloomy. If it's a thunderstorm, let cumulonimbus clouds appear. By the way, you can add the rainbow in Minecraft, but you need to make the rainbow with a small probability after a rainy day!

Vibrant Visuals Missing on Switch 2 – A Disgrace
Vibrant Visuals delivers stunning Minecraft upgrades—volumetric fog, directional lighting, enhanced water—standard on Xbox, PS5, and high-end PCs. Yet months after launch, Nintendo Switch 2 gets nothing. The community is furious: nearly 300 upvotes and dozens of comments demand a dedicated Switch 2 edition with Vibrant Visuals, higher render distance, and Joy-Con mouse mode. The hardware can handle it—original Switch runs Cyberpunk 2077 and 10,000 TNT explosions. No technical barrier exists.
So why the silence? Microsoft holds the answer. As Mojang’s owner, they prioritize Xbox and PC to funnel players into their ecosystem. Nintendo is a direct rival. Why invest in enhancing a competitor’s platform? Better to leave Switch users with outdated visuals—or push them to buy an Xbox. Negotiations with Nintendo likely stall over licensing, costs, or cold corporate strategy.
In 2025, this exclusion is outrageous. Minecraft thrives on cross-play and accessibility. Instead, an entire device family is locked out of core upgrades—not because it can’t run them, but due to corporate rivalry. It’s anti-player, anti-community, and a betrayal of Minecraft’s spirit. Switch 2 deserves Vibrant Visuals now.

1: Please add a water reflectivity slider. I believe the comments of some who say the water reflectivity makes it too hard to see underwater are actually unable to see due to fog rendering and general poor underwater visibility. Regardless, I'm sure many would love to be able to turn it down for maximum visibility during some or most gameplay, but also to be able to turn it up for ambiance and screenshots. I, personally, would DESPERATELY want to be able to take screenshots with fully reflective water.

2: Please add a caustic brightness slider in the options. This would solve many people's issues with the caustics outright, without having to impact the experience of other players.

3: Please change water caustics to darken as you get deeper. This is more realistic and aesthetic, but it would also dramatically improve visibility because, once water darkness has been improved, the blocks and the caustics will fade in tandem, keeping the bright contrast of the caustics from making blocks indistinguishable.

4: Please make caustics dimmer under flowing water, depending on the flowing water height. Having bright caustics under the very edge of a water flow is strange, unrealistic, and causes visibility issues. I would want them not to be full strength until there are 2 or three water blocks above them. That said, some players may prefer to have waterlogged blocks have the same caustic brightness as a full water block (and I assume it would be easier to code). I would have to see the difference to know what I'd prefer, honestly.

5: As others have said, the texture of the caustics needs improvement. The repetition feels harsh and out of place.

Hello again, my last feedback was in april, now I will update on what I think now about the water. 

The devs have done a great job on the water since, I am loving the reflections and the smoothing out of the water texture compared to last time which was very pixelated, now there's a good balance. However there are now still some things that need improvement:

1) Murkiness in the water has been a long issue now, even though I can definitely say that the devs have improved underwater visibility a lot compared to last time, however, visibility is still an issue, I think we need an individual settings for each underwater biome, like we have for the land ones. This murkiness can actually be solved by disabling volumetric fog, which actually makes underwater look better, so maybe having different levels of volumetric fog for each water biome would be ideal. 

2) Another issue people have pointed out since the beginning is the overly transparent water, during noon the water is way too transparent, so much so it seems like water is not even there, this does not look particularly well even people have waterfalls in their worlds, which are difficult to see at a distance due to the waters transparency.

I've been playing a lot with vibrant visuals turned on. Everything looks good for the most part, except for these two glaring issues:

* The 'milky water' effect. This is most noticeable on the surface of water which is obscured from the sun or underground. it looks AWFUL. Since I last mentioned this issue, I have noticed it also appears on the underside of the water's surface, for example if there is a tree shading the water, the shadowed area underneath the tree when viewing from under the water's surface has the same milky effect.

My proposal to fix this issue is to replace the milky effect with the colour of the water, taken from the biome's water colour. Please get in touch if this explanation doesn't make sense.

* The saturation on all colours is too high. This is jarring, and even causes artifacts around banner patterns which are in direct sunlight. The max saturation should be set to the original brightness/contrast present in the textures (if these textures are converted to HDR colourspace, I think this would work).

I would appreciate a reply from someone on the team regarding this post! Thank you :)

In Vibrant Visuals, water is way too transparent from above. You see almost everything underwater, and it's sometimes hard to tell if there's water there at all. At the horizon, where water touches the sky, there's only the slightest difference in color, and everything underwater looks extremely lit up.

In Fancy, you can still see the blue tint clearly and you can distinguish the horizon line easily. It also looks darker and dimmer in the water, so you can't see every single piece of kelp or sea grass. 

It looks more obviously like water when the sun is reflecting off of it, but that only happens from specific angles and in a few places. Most of the time, it's almost entirely transparent. 

What's strange, though, is that it's significantly darker when you're underwater. It's so dark and washed out, it's hard to see what blocks are or anything far in front of you. It doesn't make sense that you can see things extremely bright from above the water, and once you go under the surface, it's completely dark.
